question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate, professional responses. Be sure to produce executable code wherever possible. Please implement an online image clipboard tool where users can upload images, cut out specified areas, and save the cropped portions as new images. The tool should support freely selecting the size and position of the crop area, and provide real-time preview of the cropping effect.

checklist.title: Is the image upload functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the code correctly implements file selection, drag-and-drop uploads, and handles various image formats (JPG, PNG, GIF, WebP). Verify proper error handling for invalid file types and oversized images. Deduct 5 points if only basic file input is implemented without drag-and-drop, 3 points if image format validation is missing, and 2 points if there's no proper upload feedback. Score 0 if the upload functionality is not implemented at all. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the image cropping interface fully functional?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the cropping interface allows users to precisely select an area with resizable and movable selection box. Check if it provides visual guides (rule of thirds, golden ratio), aspect ratio constraints, and handles edge cases like small images. Score 0 if cropping functionality isn't implemented, 5 if only basic selection is available, and 10 if it includes advanced features like maintaining aspect ratios and intuitive resizing handles on all corners and edges. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is real-time preview of the cropped image implemented?
checklist.description: Verify that the interface shows a real-time preview of the cropped area as users adjust the selection. Check for smooth updates without performance degradation on larger images. The preview should accurately represent the final output. Score 0 if no preview exists, 5 if preview is present but not real-time or has significant lag, and 10 if preview updates instantly and accurately reflects the final output including any applied transformations. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the save/export functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Check if users can save the cropped image in multiple formats (PNG, JPG, WebP) with customizable quality settings. Verify that the download works correctly with proper filenames and maintains image quality. Score 0 if saving isn't implemented, 5 if only basic download is available with no format options, and 10 if it offers multiple export formats, quality controls, and proper file handling including fallbacks for browsers with limited support. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code handles common exceptional cases like browser incompatibilities, memory limitations with large images, and network issues during uploads. Code should gracefully degrade and provide helpful error messages. Deduct 3 points for each unhandled critical edge case (failed uploads, browser crashes with large images, CORS issues). Give 10 points if all reasonable error conditions are handled with clear user feedback, 5 points for average robustness, and 0 points if critical failures occur under normal usage scenarios.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Image enhancement tools like brightness/contrast adjustment 2. Auto-crop suggestions based on image content 3. Batch processing for multiple images 4. Cloud storage integration for processed images). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple cropping algorithms coexisting) 2. Function modules unrelated to image cropping (e.g., a built-in music player) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive animations that slow down the interface). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (separation of concerns between image processing, UI components, and storage), code reusability, and performance optimization (efficient canvas operations, proper memory management for large images). Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code has memory leaks when handling multiple images; deduct 3 points if canvas operations are inefficient and cause lag. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching that doesn't distract from the images being edited 2) Proper layout with clear separation between tools, preview area, and controls 3) Consistent UI elements with appropriate sizing for touch devices. Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic tool arrangement that hinders workflow. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the cropping interaction conforms to expected behavior: 1) Responsive selection box with no perceptible lag 2) Smooth transitional feedback when adjusting crop area 3) Intuitive controls that follow standard patterns (e.g., corner handles for resizing). Deduct 5 points for jerky movement when resizing selection, 3 points for delayed visual feedback during cropping adjustments, and 5 points for non-standard interaction patterns that confuse users. The full score is 10 points.
